Everyone who has spent some time working with git irremediably knows about 
merging. Suppose we have a branches called A coming from master…
markdownRemark.html:
Everyone who has spent some time working with git irremediably knows about merging. Suppose we have a branches called A coming from master. The merge command brings the changes carried in A into master. It does works fine, changes are placed ahead in the master branch.

71a621b (HEAD -> master, A) (A) A file updated
2dc6065 (A) new A file
d9ad32e A new commit is introduced while previous changes are in stash
13b16a5 Revert "README updated"
76a1097 Demo file updated
a31e004 README updated
44d4c5b New README file
ee42779 New demo file

The log reflects an incremental order of commits, or put in other words, the commits are shown in the same order were added. A timeline of changes.

057a856 (HEAD -> master) Merge branch 'B'
71a621b (A) (A) A file updated
1ac6aff (B) (B) B file updated
2dc6065 (A) new A file
d657116 (B) new B file
d9ad32e A new commit is introduced while previous changes are in stash
13b16a5 Revert "README updated"
76a1097 Demo file updated
a31e004 README updated
44d4c5b New README file
ee42779 New demo file
